elements.content: A fluorescent Zn­(II)–salicyaldimine coordination polymer, [Zn­(Lsalpyca)­(H2O)] n (1; H2Lsalpyca = 4-hydroxy-3-(((pyridin-2-yl)­methylimino)­methyl)­benzoic acid), showing a one-dimensional (1D) zigzag chain structure has been hydro­(solvo)­thermally synthesized. Removal of coordination water molecules in 1 by thermal dehydration gives rise to the dehydration product [Zn­(Lsalpyca)] n (1′), which has a dizinc-based two-dimensional (2D) gridlike (4,4)-layer structure. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses, and infrared (IR) spectra all clearly indicate that the structure of 1 is quite flexible as a result of a reversible 1D–2D single-crystal to single-crystal (SCSC) transformation upon removal and rebinding of coordination water molecules, which accompanies changes in coordination sphere and network dimensionality. Additionally, Zn­(II)–salicyaldimine polymers 1 and 1′ exhibit different solid-state photoluminescences at 458 and 480 nm, respectively. This is reasonably attributed to the close-packing effect and/or the influences of the differences on the conformation and the coordination mode of the Lsalpyca ligand and the coordination geometry around the Zn­(II) center.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) and/or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which represent one-, two-, or three-dimensional (1D, 2D, or 3D) periodical structures of metal ions/clusters interconnected by organic bridging ligands, are currently some of the most attractive crystalline materials in the research fields of crystal engineering, supramolecular chemistry, solid-state chemistry, and materials science not only from a fundamental structural point of view but also due to their high prospects for practical applications. An intriguing discovery regarding these CP/MOF-based crystalline materials is the stimuli-responsive framework flexibility between the solid phases with the retention of single-crystal character. These dynamic single-crystal to single-crystal (SCSC) transformations involving solid-state reactivity and structural transformation are rarely observed and normally occur merely through minor movements of atoms in the crystal. The structure–property relationship of the so-called “soft” crystalline materials which shows several types of structural flexibility of the highly ordered networks and thus is essentially distinct from that of the rigid materials has been addressed in several review articles. As representative examples, changes of the species including solvent exclusion/exchange, ligand addition/elimination/replacement, metal ion exchange, postsynthetic modifications (PSMs) on frameworks, and external physical stimuli such as heat, light, and mechanochemical force are the common driving forces to induction of characteristic SCSC transformations. This results in alternation in symmetry, lattice parameters, coordination number and geometry, network dimensionality and interpenetration, molecular stacking fashions, etc. Herein, we report a fluorescent Zn­(II)–salicyaldimine coordination polymer that exhibits reversible SCSC transformations upon removal and rebinding of coordination water molecules to form two different stable forms with a change in dimension from a 1D chain to a 2D layer accompanied by a change in coordination sphere.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) and/or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which represent one-, two-, or three-dimensional (1D, 2D, or 3D) periodical structures of metal ions/clusters interconnected by organic bridging ligands, are currently some of the most attractive crystalline materials in the research fields of crystal engineering, supramolecular chemistry, solid-state chemistry, and materials science not only from a fundamental structural point of view but also due to their high prospects for practical applications. An intriguing discovery regarding these CP/MOF-based crystalline materials is the stimuli-responsive framework flexibility between the solid phases with the retention of single-crystal character. These dynamic single-crystal to single-crystal (SCSC) transformations involving solid-state reactivity and structural transformation are rarely observed and normally occur merely through minor movements of atoms in the crystal. The structure-property relationship of the so-called "soft" crystalline materials which shows several types of structural flexibility of the highly ordered networks and thus is essentially distinct from that of the rigid materials has been addressed in several review articles. As representative examples, changes of the species including solvent exclusion/exchange, ligand addition/elimination/replacement, metal ion exchange, postsynthetic modifications (PSMs) on frameworks, and external physical stimuli such as heat, light, and mechanochemical force are the common driving forces to induction of characteristic SCSC transformations. This results in alternation in symmetry, lattice parameters, coordination number and geometry, network dimensionality and interpenetration, molecular stacking fashions, etc. Herein, we report a fluorescent Zn(II)-salicyaldimine coordination polymer that exhibits reversible SCSC transformations upon removal and rebinding of coordination water molecules to form two different stable forms with a change in dimension from a 1D chain to a 2D layer accompanied by a change in coordination sphere.

elements.content: Chemical reagents were purchased commercially and were used as received without further purification. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX-300 solution NMR spectrometer. All chemical shifts are reported in δ units with reference to the residual protons of the deuterated solvent. Coupling constants are given in hertz. Mass spectra were recorded with a Bruker Daltonics flexAnalysis matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under nitrogen with a Thermo Cahn VersaTherm HS TG analyzer with a heating rate of 1 °C/min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were recorded on a Shimadzu XRD-7000 diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at 40 kV and 30 mA. Variable-temperature XRPD patterns were recorded at the BL17A1 beamline of the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (NSRRC) TLS light source in Taiwan. The ring energy of the TLS was operated at 1.5 GeV with a typical current of 360 mA in TOP-UP mode. The wavelength of the incident X-rays was 1.321863 Å, delivered from a superconducting wavelength-shifting magnet and a Si(111) triangular crystal monochromator (TCM). The diffraction patterns were recorded using a Mar345 imaging plate detector approximately 180 mm away from sample positions with a typical exposure duration of 5 min. The pixel size of Mar345 was 100 mm. The two-dimensional diffraction pattern was converted to a one-dimensional powder diffraction profile by the program GSAS-II and cake-type integration. The diffraction angles were calibrated according to Bragg positions of LaB6 standards. The powder samples were sealed in glass capillaries and spun quickly at about 3000 rpm about to avoid the preferred orientation. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Frontier Fourier transform infrared spectrometer using the attenuated total reflection (ATR) technique. Solid-state emission spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Hitachi F7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on an Elementar Vario EL III analytical instrument.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 1 and 1′ were determined from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data and X-ray powder diffration data, respectively. For 1, data collections were performed on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini S diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Starting models for structure refinement were found using direct methods (SHELXS-97), and the structural data were refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the WINGX and SHELX-97 program packages. All non-hydrogen atoms were found from the difference Fourier maps and refined anisotropically. Carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed by geometrical calculations and refined in the riding mode. Oxygen-bound hydrogen atoms were first located on difference Fourier maps and then fixed at calculated positions and included in the final refinement. Isotropic displacement parameters of all hydrogen atoms were derived from the parent atoms. For 1′, its solid-state structure was solved by the DASH program for the structure model searching and refinement by the Jana2006 program through variable-temperature XRPD data using Taiwan Light source wiggler Powder X-ray beamline BL17A1. CCDC 1419214–1419215 contain supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. Detailed crystallographic data are summarized in .

The salicyaldimine ligand 4-hydroxy-3-(((pyridin-2-yl)­methylimino)­methyl)­benzoic acid (H2Lsalpyca), incorporating carboxylate and pyridine donating functions, was synthesized by the condensation reaction of 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzoic acid and 2-aminomethylpyridine. The Zn­(II)–salicyaldimine compound [Zn­(Lsalpyca)­(H2O)] n (1) was obtained as pale yellow crystals by the hydrothermal reaction of H2Lsalpyca and Zn­(OAc)2 in a basic (NaOH) aqueous solution ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The salicyaldimine ligand 4-hydroxy-3-(((pyridin-2-yl)methylimino)methyl)benzoic acid (H2Lsalpyca), incorporating carboxylate and pyridine donating functions, was synthesized by the condensation reaction of 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzoic acid and 2-aminomethylpyridine. The Zn(II)-salicyaldimine compound [Zn(Lsalpyca)(H2O)] n  (1) was obtained as pale yellow crystals by the hydrothermal reaction of H2Lsalpyca and Zn(OAc)2 in a basic (NaOH) aqueous solution ().

elements.clean_text: 1  Syntheses of 1, 1', and 1-R

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and has an asymmetric unit that consists of one Zn­(II) center, one molecule of Lsalpyca, and one H2O molecule bound to the Zn­(II) center. The five-coordinated Zn­(II) center with a τ value of 0.45 is surrounded by three O atoms (from one phenolato, one carboxylato, and one aqua) and two N atoms (from one imino and one pyridine) to give a geometry intermediate between square pyramidal (sp) and trigonal bipyramidal (tbp) (a). Each Lsalpyca ligand bridges two Zn­(II) centers, in which the pyridine, imine, and phenolate functions are employed to tris-chelate the first Zn­(II) center and the carboxylate group is a monodentate bridge to the second Zn­(II) center with the remaining carboxylate oxygen in very weak contact (Zn···O, 2.9937(17) Å). With respect to the plane of the phenol moiety, the plane of the pyridine ring shows a dihedral angle of 14.6°, whereas the plane of the carboxylate moiety shows a dihedral angle of 18.2°, making them nearly coplanar (dihedral angle 4.5°). The connections of Zn­(II) centers and Lsalpyca ligands forms a 1D zigzag chain structure that propagates along the crystallographic [201] direction (b). Each aqua ligand acts as a fifurcated hydrogen bond donor to a phenolate oxygen (O4–H101···O1#1: d(D···A) = 2.656(2) Å, ∠(D–H···A) = 169°, 2 – x, – y, – z; a) of an adjacent chain and an uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen (O4–H102···O3#2: d(D···A) = 2.722(2) Å, ∠(D–H···A) = 172°, 1 – x, −y, −z; b) of a second adjacent chain, resulting in two different types of hydrogen-bond-assisted 2D supramolecular layers. The whole crystal structure of 1 is therefore described as a 3D supramolecular network supported by hydrogen bonds (c).

elements.content: An interesting feature in 1 is that the hydrogen-bonded network may offer suitable conditions for a solid-state reaction to take place, since the geometric proximity between the Zn­(II) centers and the phenolate oxygens (e.g., Zn1···O1#1, 4.414 Å) or the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygens (e.g., Zn1···O3#2, 4.177 Å) from adjacent chains in 1 is held by O–H···O hydrogen bonding. Therefore, when the aqua ligands are removed, the phenolate or the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms may take up the vacant sites of Zn­(II) centers in a neighboring chain to form a covalently bonded polymeric motif.
elements.clean_text: An interesting feature in 1 is that the hydrogen-bonded network may offer suitable conditions for a solid-state reaction to take place, since the geometric proximity between the Zn(II) centers and the phenolate oxygens (e.g., Zn1⋅⋅⋅O1#1, 4.414 Å) or the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygens (e.g., Zn1⋅⋅⋅O3#2, 4.177 Å) from adjacent chains in 1 is held by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding. Therefore, when the aqua ligands are removed, the phenolate or the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms may take up the vacant sites of Zn(II) centers in a neighboring chain to form a covalently bonded polymeric motif.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of 1 reveals that the aqua ligands were released between ca. 100 and 117 °C (found 6.4%, calcd 5.3%) and then the dehydrated phase began to decompose when the temperature was raised to near 310 °C (). The decomposition process ended at around 460 °C to give the final residue of ZnO (found 23.7%, calcd 24.1%). Variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of 1 show a new phase formation when the temperature is higher than 130 °C (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Accordingly, when a crystalline sample of 1 is heated at a temperature of 160 °C for 1 h, all of the aqua ligands are released from the structure to give a dehydration product [Zn­(Lsalpyca)] n (1′; ), confirmed by TG analysis and supported by elementary analysis, and this results in conversion to a new solid-state phase, as shown by the XRPD patterns, accompanied by a color change from bright yellow to dull yellow (b,c). The TG curve of 1′ shows a long plateau before a decomposition process occurs between ca. 310 and 460 °C (), leaving a final residue of 25.6% weight percentage assigned to ZnO (calcd 25.5%). The XRPD pattern of 1′ is comparable with that found for 1, where the (101̅) reflection is drastically shifted from a low angle of 11.76° in 1 to a high angle of 12.32° in 1′ and the peak intensity of the (023) reflection with 2θ of 24.85° in 1 is reduced in 1′ (b,c).

elements.content: The crystal of 1′ bears a close relationship to that of 1they have the same crystal system (monoclinic) and space group (P21/c) and very similar cell parameters (). The asymmetric unit of 1′ consists of only one Zn­(II) center and one molecule of Lsalpyca. The Lsalpyca ligands coordinate to the Zn­(II) centers through the pyridine-imine-phenolate tris-chelator to give a phenolate-bridged dimer, with a Zn···Zn distance of 3.258 Å, and employ the carboxylate group to monodentately bridge the third Zn­(II) center, where the remaining carboxylate oxygen is also in weak contact with the Zn­(II) center (Zn···O, 2.874 Å; a). The dihedral angles are 28.0° between the plane of the phenol moiety and the plane of the pyridine ring, 23.2° between the plane of the phenol moiety and the plane of the carboxylate moiety, and 50.8° between the plane of the pyridine ring and the plane of the carboxylate moiety. These data indicates that the conformation of the Lsalpyca ligand in 1′ is more twisted in comparison with that in 1, as a result of the SCSC structural transformation. In turn, the Zn­(II) center adopts a five-coordinate tbp/sp intermediate geometry (τ = 0.59), made up of two phenolate and one carboxylate oxygen atom and one imine and one pyridine nitrogen atom. On comparison with the structure of 1, the formation of an additional Zn–Ophenolate coordination bond takes place along with removal of the Zn–OH2 coordination bond; thus, the coordination number of the Zn­(II) centers does not change. However, this change in network is noticeable in which the aqua ligand in 1 is now replaced by a phenolate oxygen atom from a neighboring chain, thus giving rise to a dizinc-based 2D layer structure in 1′ that can be regarded as a topological gridlike (4,4)-net by considering each phenolate-bridged dimer as a node (b).

elements.content: On the basis of the crystallographic studies, the transformation from 1 to 1′ involves changes in lattice parameters, network connectivity and dimensionality, and coordination sphere, but not in coordination number and geometry. Removal of the aqua ligands in 1 by thermal dehydration has reduced the unit cell volume of the compound by about 11% from 1340.42(9) Å3 (1) to 1192.50(11) Å3 (1′), a clear indication of crystal contraction. When the structure is viewed down the crystallographic a axis, it is quite obvious that the key atom in the SCSC structural transformation from the 1D zigzag chain 1 to the 2D gridlike layer 1′ is the phenolate oxygen (O1). Replacement of O–H···Ophenolate hydrogen bonds in 1 has taken place by Zn–Ophenolate rather than Zn–Ocarboxylate coordination bonds in 1′ (), which is reasonably attributed to the minimal atom movements and ligand-conformational changes without a drastic change on the crystal packing during dehydration. In our observations, adjacent 1D chains, after thermal dehydration, have slightly slipped in opposite directions along the Zn1–O1#1 vector to bring Zn1 and O1#1 into a very close contact of 2.278 Å, where formerly a distance of 4.414 Å was observed in 1. This unambiguously confirms a new Zn–Ophenolate bond formation and thus results in transformation from a hydrogen-bonded network in 1 to a covalent-bonded framework in 1′. In addition, this change has simultaneously shortened the related Zn1···Zn1#1 distance from 5.334 Å in 1 to 3.258 Å in 1′.

elements.content: Notably, the reversibility of the transformation is achieved which has been supported by the XRPD, TG analysis, and IR studies. When the solid sample of anhydrous 1′ was exposed to a moist atmosphere over 7 days, a solid-state rehydration product, 1-R, was formed (). Acceptable matches in XRPD diffractograms were observed between the experimental diffraction patterns for 1-R and 1 (d), suggesting that 1-R regains the original structure of 1 accompanying crystal expansion and dimensionality change upon rebinding water molecules. This is further supported by the TG analysis of 1-R, which is almost identical with that of 1a 6.0% weight loss for releasing aqua ligand in comparison with the calculated value of 5.3% and a weight of 24.2% final residue for ZnO in comparison with the calculated value of 24.1% (). In addition to XRPD and TG analysis, the IR spectra of as-synthesized 1, dehydrated 1′, and rehydrated 1-R also indicate the same observations on reversible coordination-sphere and structure changes associated with the breakage/formation of chemical bonds (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). Consequently, the above findings clearly show that the structure of 1 is quite flexible and dynamic because it undergoes a reversible 1D–2D SCSC structural transformation with significant crystal contraction and expansion driven by dehydration and rehydration.

elements.content: Apart from water, we have also explored the possibility of adsorbing or coordinating other Lewis base solvents, such as acetonitrile (MeCN), pyridine (py), and methanol (MeOH), by anhydrous 1′. When the powder samples of anhydrous 1′ were separately exposed to a saturated acetonitrile and pyridine atmosphere for 7 days, the so-obtained solid materials, 1′/MeCN and 1′/py, show nearly identical XRPD diffractograms and IR spectra in comparison with those found for anhydrous 1′ (Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information), meaning that the dehydrated phase 1′ seems cannot adsorb acetonitrile and pyridine molecules. This may be partially attributed to their large size. On the other hand, when the adsorbing experiment was carried out with the use of wet methanol, the so-obtained solid material 1′/MeOH shows similar XRPD patterns in comparison with that found for 1 (Figure S4), hinting that 1′/MeOH regains the original structure of 1: i.e., the adsorbate in 1′/MeOH is water. The IR spectra and TGA data of 1′/MeOH also draw the same conclusion (Figures S5 and S6 in the Supporting Information). These results clearly indicate that anhydrous 1′ can selectively adsorb water molecules over other Lewis base solvents and may be applied in dehumidifying.

These results clearly indicate that anhydrous 1' can selectively adsorb water molecules over other Lewis base solvents and may be applied in dehumidifying.

elements.content: The solid-state photoluminescent properties of the organic ligand H2Lsalpyca and Zn­(II)–salicyaldimine compounds 1, 1′, and 1-R were spectroscopically investigated at room temperature (), and photographs of these materials under sunlight and UV illumination are provided in Figure S7 in the Supporting Information. Upon excitation at λex 330 nm, compound 1 gives an emission peak at λem 458 nm, which is in good agreement with that (λem 496 nm) of H2Lsalpyca and is tentatively assigned to an intraligand (π → π*) transition. On the other hand, anhydrous 1′ displays an emission peak at λem 480 nm, showing a 22 nm red shift in comparison with that of 1. We ascribe this red shift to the close-packing effect of the Lsalpydc ligands in 1′, which effectively lessens the energy gap. However, with consideration of the crystal structures of 1 and 1′, the differences in the conformation and the coordination mode of the Lsalpyca ligand and the coordination structural geometry around the Zn­(II) center might also be reasons for the change in photoluminescence. After the structure recovers to 1, i.e., 1-R, by gently reabsorbing the lost water content over 7 days, the emission peak at λem 453 nm in the solid state is in agreement with that of as-made 1.

elements.content: In this work, we have successfully synthesized the fluorescent Zn­(II)–salicyaldimine compound 1 having a zigzag chain structure. The most important feature of the crystal of 1 is that it exhibits a breathing SCSC structural transformation upon removal and rebinding of coordination water molecules, which accompanies reversible dimensionality changes between a 1D chain and a 2D layer involving significant chemical rearrangement without drastic changes in crystalline topology and packing. In addition, the dehydrated compound 1′ can selectively adsorb H2O molecules and reject other adsorbates such as acetonitrile, pyridine, and methanol.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, we have successfully synthesized the fluorescent Zn(II)-salicyaldimine compound 1 having a zigzag chain structure. The most important feature of the crystal of 1 is that it exhibits a breathing SCSC structural transformation upon removal and rebinding of coordination water molecules, which accompanies reversible dimensionality changes between a 1D chain and a 2D layer involving significant chemical rearrangement without drastic changes in crystalline topology and packing. In addition, the dehydrated compound 1' can selectively adsorb H2O molecules and reject other adsorbates such as acetonitrile, pyridine, and methanol.

To a solution of 2-aminopyridine (108.1 mg, 1.0 mmol) in 2 mL of methanol was added a solution of 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzoic acid (166.0 mg, 1.0 mmol) in 6 mL of methanol under a nitrogen atmosphere. After the mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature, the solvent was removed under reduced pressure and analytically pure yellow powdered product of H2Lsalpyca was obtained after filtering, washing with distilled water, and drying in air. Yield: 48% (123.0 mg, 8.8 mmol). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6, ppm): δ 8.84 (s, 1H), 8.55 (d, J = 3.9 Hz, 1H), 8.11 (s, 1H), 7.88–7.79 (m, 2H), 7.42 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.33 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 1H), 6.87 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 4.93 (s, 2H). The bomb was placed in an oven maintained at 80 °C for 72 h and then cooled to 30 °C. Pale yellow rodlike crystals were obtained in a yield of 70% (0.9 mg). Accordingly, when a crystalline sample of 1 is heated at a temperature of 160 °C for 1 h, all of the aqua ligands are released from the structure to give a dehydration product [Zn­(Lsalpyca)] n (1′; ), confirmed by TG analysis and supported by elementary analysis, and this results in conversion to a new solid-state phase, as shown by the XRPD patterns, accompanied by a color change from bright yellow to dull yellow (b,c). The TG curve of 1′ shows a long plateau before a decomposition process occurs between ca. 310 and 460 °C (), leaving a final residue of 25.6% weight percentage assigned to ZnO (calcd 25.5%). The XRPD pattern of 1′ is comparable with that found for 1, where the (101̅) reflection is drastically shifted from a low angle of 11.76° in 1 to a high angle of 12.32° in 1′ and the peak intensity of the (023) reflection with 2θ of 24.85° in 1 is reduced in 1′ (b,c).

The solid-state photoluminescent properties of the organic ligand H2Lsalpyca and Zn­(II)–salicyaldimine compounds 1, 1′, and 1-R were spectroscopically investigated at room temperature (), and photographs of these materials under sunlight and UV illumination are provided in Figure S7 in the Supporting Information. Upon excitation at λex 330 nm, compound 1 gives an emission peak at λem 458 nm, which is in good agreement with that (λem 496 nm) of H2Lsalpyca and is tentatively assigned to an intraligand (π → π*) transition. On the other hand, anhydrous 1′ displays an emission peak at λem 480 nm, showing a 22 nm red shift in comparison with that of 1. We ascribe this red shift to the close-packing effect of the Lsalpydc ligands in 1′, which effectively lessens the energy gap. However, with consideration of the crystal structures of 1 and 1′, the differences in the conformation and the coordination mode of the Lsalpyca ligand and the coordination structural geometry around the Zn­(II) center might also be reasons for the change in photoluminescence. After the structure recovers to 1, i.e., 1-R, by gently reabsorbing the lost water content over 7 days, the emission peak at λem 453 nm in the solid state is in agreement with that of as-made 1.

The decomposition process ended at around 460 °C to give the final residue of ZnO (found 23.7%, calcd 24.1%). Variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of 1 show a new phase formation when the temperature is higher than 130 °C (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information).
